Between rationing and a collaborationist past, the first holidays for Vichy's children after World War II
description: '1945, a French Summer' (5/6). In the aftermath of the war, the Vichy city council sought to restore the town's status as the 'capital of thermal spas.' At the same time, secular groups and religious institutions worked to offer children a summer break before the new school year began.

New clashes rock Syria's Druze heartland as tribal fighters reinforce Bedouin
description: The violence erupted a day after the army withdrew under Israeli bombardment and diplomatic pressure; about 200 tribal fighters clashed with armed Druze men from the city using machine guns and shells, leading the United Nations to call for an end to the 'bloodshed' as well as an 'independent' investigation.

headline: Tour de France: Pogacar dominates stage 13 time trial to extend lead
description: The Slovenian star stunned rivals with an uphill victory on a road bike, stretching his overall lead to over four minutes as the Tour heads into its brutal final week.

headline: CBS network cancels Stephen Colbert's long-running talk show 'The Late Show'
description: The show will end in 2026, ending the decades-old 'Late Show' franchise that began with David Letterman in 1993. The announcement came just days after Colbert criticized CBS' parent company Paramount for its $16 million settlement with Trump, calling it 'a big fat bribe.'

headline: In Syria, a cycle of revenge engulfs the Druze city of Sweida
description: Attacks against Druze civilians, allegedly carried out by members of government forces, have multiplied in recent days in the city of Sweida and its surrounding areas, which remain cut off from the outside world. These attacks have triggered retaliatory violence against Bedouins.

In 1945, 'Elle' instantly set a new standard for French women's magazines
description: 'The Summer of 1945' (4/6). Hélène Gordon-Lazareff, who spent much of World War Two in the United States, returned to France with fresh ideas for the press. She promised her readers 'seriousness in frivolity, irony in gravity.'

headline: In Rome, the re-enchanted gardens of the Villa Medici
description: As famous as the Renaissance palace they surround, the gardens of the French Academy in Italy have just been redesigned by artists and landscape architects. Initiated by the director of the institution, this enhancement of the botanical heritage highlights citrus trees, the emblematic fruits of the area.

headline: These French villages have no more drinking water. The reason? PFAS pollution
description: Nearly 3,500 residents across 16 rural villages have been unable to drink tap water since July 10 due to a record-breaking contamination by PFAS, a group of toxic substances known as 'forever chemicals.'
